author: Anna Kitanaka
title: Japanese Stocks Follow U.S. Lower as Oil Leads Commodities Rout
text:
Japanese stocks fell, following U.S. equities lower, after Brent crude oil dropped below $50 a barrel amid a commodities rout.
Oil explorer Inpex Corp. slipped 1.7 percent. Fishing company Maruha Nichiro Corp. tumbled 4.1 percent after reporting a 44 percent drop in net income. Suzuki Motor Corp. jumped 3.6 percent, rising for a second day after the hedge fund of activist investor Daniel Loeb said it took a stake in the carmaker. Otsuka Corp. added 5.3 percent as the drugmaker’s profit jumped.
The Topix index dropped 0.2 percent to 1,655.71 as of 9:22 a.m. in Tokyo, with five stocks falling for every three that rose. The Nikkei 225 Stock Average slipped 0.3 percent to 20,478.02. Bloomberg gauges of the world’s biggest energy producers and miners tumbled to six-year lows.
“The two negative factors for Japanese stocks today are the concerns over China and cheaper U.S. stocks caused by falling commodity prices,” Toshihiko Matsuno, chief strategist at SMBC Friend Securities Co. in Tokyo said by phone. “Domestic earnings will act as a support.”
China imposed limits on equity short selling late Monday in its latest salvo aimed at quelling stock volatility. Those who borrow shares will have to wait a day to repay the loans, according to statements.
More than 90 companies in the Topix will report quarterly results Tuesday. Of the firms that have reported results this season and for which estimates are available, 61 percent exceeded profit expectations, an improvement from the 48 percent that beat forecasts in the previous quarter, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
Commodities Rout E-mini futures on the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index slipped 0.2 percent after the underlying measure lost 0.3 percent on Monday in New York as the Institute for Supply Management’s U.S. manufacturing index slid from a five-month high.
Brent futures dropped 5.2 percent to settle at $49.52 a barrel on Monday, the lowest close in six months.
Mining companies and oil producers tumbled worldwide as a renewed slide in commodity prices saw crude drop to a six-month low on speculation Iran can boost supply, and copper approach a bear market on concern Chinese economic growth is slowing.
The Bloomberg Commodity Index is at the lowest level since 2002. The Bloomberg World Oil & Gas Index of 65 of the leading producers declined 2 percent to its weakest in six years. The Bloomberg World Mining Index of the biggest mining stocks fell 1.9 percent to near its lowest since March 10, 2009.
